page.title: 17PINDEN END FARM QUARRY
page.content: Chalk quarrying began in 1916 to provide lime for hand-made bricks in the local brickfields. The exception- ally pure calcium carbonate produced was later used to manufacture white- wash, but the works were closed down after the development of synthetic paints. Production then switched to agricultural lime, and now 20,000 tons are quarried annually. The lime is distributed throughout{Kent, Sussex, { Hertfordshire}and{Suffolk}and is also exported to many parts of the world. As it is very soft and pure, with a calcium carbonate content of 98.4%, the lime is used in several trades, including steel production, the fur and cosmetic trades, and in ornamental plaster work. The flints extracted during quarrying are not discarded but pulverized and used to glaze pottery and restore ancient monuments.
